As you climb down, the trapdoor closes above you with a soft thud. The creature's movements overhead become muffled but continue—a methodical search of the saloon.

The cellar is surprisingly large, extending beyond what should be the footprint of the building above. Ancient stone walls suggest this space predates the saloon, possibly serving as the foundation for multiple buildings.

Exploring by feel in the darkness, you discover that the cellar connects to a tunnel system. Cool air flows from deeper passages, carrying with it the scent of earth and something else—something metallic and ozone-like.

Sullivan's ghost materializes beside you, his form dimmer but still visible. "Smart choice," he whispers. "These tunnels connect most of the buildings in town. The miners dug them for storage and transport."
"But be careful," he continues. "Some of these passages lead directly to the mine. And that's where they're strongest."

You hear scraping sounds from above as the creature continues its search. Sullivan points toward a passage that slopes upward. "That way leads to the edge of town. You can surface near the old water tower and make your way to your car."
But another passage beckons—one that slopes downward into deeper darkness. Strange symbols are carved into its entrance, and a faint, rhythmic pulsing seems to emanate from within.

choices.text: Follow Sullivan's advice to the surface

chapter-5f.title: Chapter 5: Frozen in Fear
text: You force yourself to remain absolutely motionless, barely daring to breathe. The creature above continues its methodical search, and you can hear it moving bottles and glasses on the bar.

Minutes pass like hours. Your muscles ache from maintaining the cramped position, but you don't dare shift. The mist continues to swirl around your feet, but strangely, it doesn't seem to affect you while you remain completely still.
Eventually, the creature's movements become less focused. The searching sounds fade, replaced by a different kind of activity—almost like it's cleaning or organizing the bar area.

Sullivan's ghost reappears, pressing a ghostly finger to his lips in a gesture for continued silence. He points upward and mouths the words: "It's one of the original miners. Miller, I think. Poor bastard."
The ghost continues: "They're not evil, just... changed. Lost. They remember their old routines, their old purposes. Miller always helped clean up after closing time."
After what feels like an eternity, the footsteps move away from the bar. You hear the saloon doors creak open and swing shut. Sullivan nods that it's safe.
"It'll be back," he warns. "They patrol the buildings at night, looking for... I don't know what. Maybe other survivors. Maybe something else entirely."
Through a crack in the floorboards above, you can see that full darkness has fallen. The unnatural aurora from the mine casts shifting patterns of light through the saloon windows.

choices.text: Try to sneak out now while it's gone

chapter-5g.title: Chapter 5: Alley Escape
text: You navigate carefully around the overturned furniture to reach the back door. It opens with a creak that sounds impossibly loud in the tense silence, but nothing immediate happens.
The alley behind the saloon is narrow and littered with debris from decades of abandonment. Broken crates, rusted equipment, and scattered papers create an obstacle course in the dim light.

Following Sullivan's directions, you locate the old mine cart tracks—twin lines of rusted metal that curve around the edge of town. The path they create offers cover behind buildings while avoiding the main streets.
As you move along the tracks, you notice they're not as abandoned as they first appeared. The metal, while rusted, shows recent disturbance—as if heavy weights have been moving along them regularly.
Strange sounds echo through the alleys—not footsteps, but sliding, flowing noises. Sometimes accompanied by what might be whispered conversations in a language you don't recognize.

The tracks lead toward a cluster of abandoned mining equipment near the town's edge. From there, you can see your car, but the direct route is blocked by several of the transformed townspeople standing in perfect formation.

An alternative presents itself: a maintenance shed near the equipment contains what looks like an old mining cart. If the tracks are still functional, you might be able to use it to coast silently to a point closer to your vehicle.

choices.text: Wait for the figures to move

chapter-5h.title: Chapter 5: Window Break
text: The window is your best bet for a quick escape, despite the noise risk. You grab a bar rag to muffle the sound and carefully work at the old window latch.
The mechanism is stuck with decades of rust and dirt. As you struggle with it, the creature upstairs moves directly overhead. Dust rains down from the ceiling with each heavy footfall.
Finally, the latch gives way with a sharp crack. You freeze, listening. The footsteps above pause, then resume with increased urgency—the creature knows something has changed.
You push the window open and squeeze through just as heavy footsteps thunder down the stairs. The creature has abandoned all pretense of stealth.

Landing in the alley outside, you can hear the thing crashing around inside the saloon, overturning furniture in its search. Through the window, you catch a glimpse of it—tall, unnaturally thin, moving with jerky motions like a marionette.

The alley offers two directions: toward the main street where your car waits, or deeper into the maze of back passages between buildings. From the main street comes the sound of more movement—you're not the only thing active in Prosperity tonight.
Behind you, glass shatters as the creature discovers your escape route. It won't be long before it follows.

choices.text: Head for the main street and your car
Lose yourself in the back alleys

chapter-6a.title: Chapter 6: The Heart of Darkness
text: The mine entrance beckons with its unnatural aurora. Despite every survival instinct screaming warnings, you step across the threshold into the tunnel.
The walls are lined with the same crystalline growths you observed outside, but here they pulse with internal light, creating a living constellation that guides your way deeper underground.

The tunnel slopes downward at a steep angle, far beyond what any normal mine shaft would attempt. The supporting timbers become less frequent, then disappear entirely as the passage transforms from human construction to something else entirely.

The rhythmic pulsing grows stronger with each step, and you realize it's not just sound—it's affecting your vision, your balance, your very thoughts. Colors that have no names flicker at the edges of your perception.

After what feels like hours but could be minutes, the tunnel opens into a vast underground chamber. The space is impossibly large, its ceiling lost in darkness above. At the center lies a pool of liquid that defies description—not quite mercury, not quite light, constantly shifting and moving with purposeful patterns.
Around the pool's edge stand dozens of figures—the missing townspeople of Prosperity. Their eyes reflect the pool's strange radiance, and they turn toward you with expressions of serene welcome.

One steps forward—a woman in a mining engineer's outfit from the 1950s. When she speaks, her voice harmonizes with itself in impossible ways: "Welcome, seeker. You've found what we found. The question now is: will you choose to understand?"

choices.text: Try to back away and escape
